section.name: TOPICS IN LITERATURE: MODERNIST SHORT STORY

comments: This is a freshman seminar in the English Department, and topics change year to year. This semester focused on the Modernist Short Story. The seminar covered stories and story-sequences by James Joyce, William Faulkner, Franz Kafka, Katherine Mansfield, Willa Cather, Sherwood Anderson, and Jean Rhys. The course began with detective fiction (Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes tales) and modernist precursors (Poe and Anton Chekhov). The course ended with the resurgence of moral realism after 1950, studying writers concerned with fundamental questions of good and evil (Flannery O'Connor, Muriel Spark, Shirley Jackson).  This course asked what makes memorable stories tick, how story-sequences compare to novels, and why the novel (a genre in which many of our writers were accomplished experts) came in the long run to eclipse short stories in the world of fiction. Written requirements included one 5-page critical essay, one 10-page critical essay, and five informal response papers. Fulfills Sector 6 of the English Standard Major.  Students raved about the class, praising the material and the class discussions. As one student said, “I've learned more than I thought I could.” More than one student said they “absolutely loved this class.” There was a range of students in the class, including majors and non-majors, and it was recommended “to any student who's interested in the humanities, or interested in knowledge for its own sake at all.”   Professor Esty was described as “amazing,” “excellent,” “knowledgeable, approachable, and enthusiastic.” Each student review praised him; as one student said, “everyone loves Professor Esty.” They described his passion for the material as “contagious,” which made for “live and thoughful” discussion. Students further said that he gave valuable suggestions and “presented issues and views that were not considered.”   Students agreed that the readings were “great,” “interesting,” and “fun to discuss in class.” The workload was seen as rigorous but “quite manageable.” The papers were seen as useful practice for a range of academic subjects.   (This review is based off the seven student comments that were submitted.)
